title: Monday, 12th February, 2018

BE11:23am

We visited IQE's facilities on Friday in Newport, South Wales to confirm the authenticity of the CSC joint venture and walk around the new wafer plant that may be supplying the maker of iPhones this summer. NB. Current supplies are from existing capacity. Following the release of ‘bear reports’ last week that questioned the validity of the CSC joint venture, we decided to see for ourselves. During our visit we walked around CSC's premises and met with its CEO. We note that late on Friday the University of Cardiff made an announcement rejecting the claims made in the ‘bear reports’, and this announcement has since been released by IQE ogether with notification of a change of auditor to KPMG from PWC, who have been in place
since 2005 and leave with a statement saying there are no matters that need to be brought to the members' attention.

red I thought that was GS Miss Piggy?
11:23 am
BE11:23am

An extract from the Cardiff University statement says – ‘Co-owned and controlled by Cardiff University and IQE, CSC applies corporate standards of governance including an independent chair, regular joint board meetings, annual reports and published accounts’. This release, together with our own visit to the site, leaves us fully convinced of CSC's existence, that it has its own employees, an independent board and most importantly, it looks set to be a significant player in the South Wales compound semiconductor cluster that is being enthusiastically supported by the UK government, as it attempts to bring manufacturing jobs back to the UK. We also took the opportunity to walk around the new facility for 100 MOCVD machines, equivalent to IQEs total current machine count of over 10 locations globally, just as installation of the first machine was completed. IQE states that this plant will be the largest and most modern of its kind anywhere in the world. We believe it is important for investors to understand that it is the mass production of VCSELs and not the license sales made to JVs in 2015 and 2016 that was the principal reason for the strong performance of IQE's shares last year. We be

Given favorable macro conditions, we see sustainably high cash returns for steelmakers near term. We expect Russian steel sector EBITDA margins of 24% over the next three years vs. a 20% average in the past decade - still far from the 2007-08 peak, but an improvement from decade averages. Healthy balance sheets and continued cash generation should support dividends and we expect our companies to continue directing c.100% of FCF to payouts.

erlkin i think the miners in US gained the most from tax reform...on a percentage basis as well
BE11:36am

Post recent market sell-off (Russian steel stocks down c.7% in 1 week), the sector offers good value with an average NTM EV/EBITDA multiple of 5.1x, a 11% discount to the historical average. At spot commodity prices, the sector trades at a 4.4x NTM EV/EBITDA, a 25% discount versus history. We think the market is still ignoring sector’s strong free cash flow (2018 FCF yield of c.12% average) and high capacity and propensity to pay dividends (2018 dividend yield of c.10% average).

Capex guidance of ~$100m is higher than consensus at $65m and marginally below Citi at $110m. The group expects resolution in Tanzania during 1H18.

TKZ if TSLA is to be punished this year which I think it will be, (say down to below 200), what would be the best strategy to short, limiting loss if any (you can never tell Musk might not incorporate this into Space X).
BE11:53am

Along with Steve Collar, who's currently CEO of SES Networks. Where his record's been ..... mixed, let's say.

BE11:53am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Steve Collar has run the expansionary part of SES, and we think the market will likely welcome his appointment. SES's comment that there will be continuity in strategy may be treated more cautiously. We think this announcement could also lead the market to question the outlook for 2018: (i) the dividend is uncovered on our numbers out to 2022; (ii) organic revenue growth is at c-4% in 2017 and the market was looking, on the back of new capacity, for c1.2% growth in 2018; this could come down; (iii) the EBITDA margin - which we estimate has fallen to 65% to 2017 - could come under further pressure.

BE11:54am

And RBC .....

#REF! @Otter easily pleased, like it
wayneJ Satellites is a theme I have been playing - increased fibre penetration / broadband wireline and wireless penetration raises issues for satellite bandwidth.
BE11:54am

Possible causes for the departure (our views)
#1 Profit Warning at FY results? With the FY results due in 11 days' time and very poor 9m results to date, the obvious first reason could be a substantial profit warning due to poor trading in the quarter to December. While the 4Q is unlikely to be good, we think a really bad 4Q performance is unlikely to be the cause as SES is bound by both French and Luxembourg reporting requirements to disclose this ahead of scheduled results if 4Q was materially very weak.
#2 Poor 2018 guidance? A more likely cause could be very weak 2018 guidance. Since this is not a backward looking metric (like 4Q results) the company would not be required to pre-announce. In our most recent note (Upgrade to Sector Perform, 9th Jan 2018) we looked in detail at the contribution from the large number of satellites launched through 2017 and 2018, and the impact these would have on growth. Our conclusion was that 2018 would see growth of c.0.8% on a constant-currency basis and 2019 would see growth of over 4% with the growth rates driven by the timing and ramp-up of the various satellites. Within our calculation we assumed a positive contribution from the new satellites offset by continued attrition within the existing business. While some of the new capacity is slightly delayed (see SES-14 below), the most likely cause of weak 2018 guidance, if this is the cause of the departure, would be continued very poor video performance.
#3 SES -14? SES launched SES-14 in late January 2018. SES 14 is one of the main satellites forming its HTS/ Mobility strategy. Unfortunately that satellite experienced an anomaly on launch, which saw it released into the wrong transfer orbit. SES has said it is using its own power to move to the correct orbital location. When this has happened previously it has usually caused a reduction in useful economic life of the satellite due to fuel usage repositioning the satellite, however this does not appear to be the case as the company has confirmed that it will have the same useful economic life but will be 4 weeks late in starting. We believe this explanation fits with the satellite being moved via electric propulsion rather than hydrazine chemical propulsion.
#4 Strategy change? The outgoing CEO was very focused on strategy, in particular the absorption of O3b and a more data-focused future and a hybrid LEO/MEO architecture. While there are unanswered questions about some of the elements of the strategy the fact that Steve Collar, who is CEO of SES Networks – which sits at the heart of this strategy - suggests to us that the broad strategy is likely to remain similar.
#5 Financial issue? SES highlighted revenue loss at MX1 at its 3Q results. SES acquired RR Media in July 2016 folding the business into its existing SES Platform Services business and renaming the unit MX1. The acquisition became acrimonious with MX1 suing several of the former executives amid accusations of improper behaviour (see Globes Business News, 5 March 2017). SES CEO said on the 3Q conference call that “the litigation is a very separate topic. There is always going to be in corporate lives, litigations. And we're very transparent. We are proactive about it. And as we progress on this front, we would update the investment community on these.“
Steve Collar: Steve Collar is the new CEO. He joins from SES Networks. He was previously CEO of O3b having been with SES since its acquisition of New Skies in 2005. His presentations at previous SES investor days have generally been well received, and certainly come across well.
Andrew Browne: The new CFO will be Andrew Browne, who was previously SES’ CFO between 2010-2013. He left SES to become the CFO of O3b. We believe his decision to leave SES may have been a personal one as his family is based in the Netherlands, as is O3b, which is based in the Hague. SES is of course based in Betzdorf in Luxembourg.

Whilst the weak H1 trading comes as no real surprise given previous guidance (H1 sales down 29%), evidence of a post-Christmas recovery in momentum has failed to emerge leading to management guiding to FY2018 underlying EBITDA in a range £6-7m (SC previously forecast £9.1m). We downgrade our EBITDA FY2018 forecast to the lower end of the range at £6.33m, and our CPTP forecast by 34% to £5.3m, EPS of 5.1p. A dividend policy with a 50% pay-out ratio see our DPS forecast cut to 2.57p

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

We forecast a reduction in net debt in FY2019 to £9.2m, again reflecting lower working capital requirements and dividend cash outflow. Our expectations results in FY2019 debt/EBITDA leverage at a still comfortable 1.4x (2.0x lease adjusted) with fixed charge cover also robust at 5.2x.
On our revised forecasts, UP Global Sourcing stock is trading on a FY2018 PER of 11.7x, falling to 11.2x and an EV/EBITDA multiple of 9.6x falling to 8.7x, with a forecast dividend yield of 4.3%. UP's share price has clearly been reflecting concerns of a sustained challenging trading environment and unfortunately today’s update has confirmed such concerns. The share price clearly need to digest the ongoing challenges faced by the business, which is expected to next update the market with interim results on 30th April.
